understandingAnxiety.title: Understanding Anxiety
understandingAnxiety.subtitle: Learn about the nature of anxiety and its impact on your life
understandingAnxiety.p1: Anxiety is, at its core, your body‚Äôs built-in alarm system. It is designed to protect you from danger by preparing you to react quickly‚Äîwhether that means fighting, running away, or freezing until the threat passes. In small amounts, this reaction is actually helpful. It‚Äôs what keeps you sharp before an important exam, makes you double-check your work before sending it, or gives you the energy to handle a stressful situation.
understandingAnxiety.p2: But when this alarm goes off too strongly or too often, especially when there is no real danger around, anxiety stops being useful. Instead of helping you, it begins to interfere with your life. What once was a natural response to keep you safe can start to feel overwhelming and constant, leaving you exhausted and unsure of yourself.
understandingAnxiety.p3: Anxiety doesn‚Äôt just live in your thoughts‚Äîit shows up in your body too. Maybe your mind races with ‚Äúwhat if‚Äù scenarios that never seem to end, or you find it hard to concentrate because your thoughts jump from one worry to another. At the same time, your body might react with a pounding heartbeat, sweaty palms, tense muscles, or a sense of restlessness that doesn‚Äôt seem to fade. Even sleep, which should give you rest, can be disrupted, leaving you feeling tired but unable to switch off.
understandingAnxiety.p4: Over time, this constant state of alertness can shape your daily life. Simple routines start to feel like uphill battles, social situations might feel unsafe, and you may catch yourself avoiding places or events that once felt normal. Your physical health can also take a hit‚Äîstress has a way of wearing down the body. And slowly, your confidence begins to shrink, as if anxiety has convinced you that you‚Äôre not as capable of coping as you truly are.
understandingAnxiety.p5: The important thing to remember is that anxiety is not permanent and it is treatable. You are not broken, and you are not alone. By learning how anxiety works‚Äîhow it affects your thoughts, your body, and your behaviors‚Äîyou can begin to take back control. With the right tools, whether that‚Äôs therapy, breathing techniques, or small lifestyle changes, it is absolutely possible to quiet the alarm, calm your system, and live a life where anxiety no longer runs the show.

panicDisorderExplained.title: Panic Disorder Explained
panicDisorderExplained.subtitle: Explore the causes and symptoms of panic disorder.
panicDisorderExplained.p1: Panic disorder often feels as if it comes out of nowhere‚Äîyou might be sitting in a caf√©, walking in the park, or even relaxing at home when suddenly your body and mind go into full alarm. Your heart races, your chest tightens, your vision may blur, and your mind screams, ‚ÄúSomething is terribly wrong. I can‚Äôt breathe. I might collapse.‚Äù The fear feels so real that many people believe they‚Äôre having a medical emergency the first time it happens.
panicDisorderExplained.p2: What‚Äôs actually happening is that your body‚Äôs fight-or-flight system has been activated in the absence of real danger. This system is designed to protect you in life-threatening situations‚Äîlike running from a predator or reacting to an accident‚Äîbut in panic disorder, it fires at the wrong time. A small physical sensation, like a skipped heartbeat or a dizzy moment, gets misinterpreted as a threat, and your body responds with a full-blown alarm.
panicDisorderExplained.p3: Once you‚Äôve experienced a panic attack, your brain remembers it. You may start to live in anticipation of the next one, scanning your body constantly for signs of trouble. This ‚Äúfear of fear‚Äù becomes its own trigger: the worry about having another attack can actually set one off. That‚Äôs why panic disorder feels so relentless‚Äînot only do the attacks themselves feel overwhelming, but the waiting, the hyper-awareness, and the dread in between can be just as exhausting.
panicDisorderExplained.p4: Over time, many people start to avoid situations where attacks have happened before‚Äîcrowded places, public transport, meetings, or even leaving the house. Avoidance brings short-term relief, but it also strengthens the belief that those situations are dangerous, which makes the cycle even harder to break.
panicDisorderExplained.p5: It‚Äôs important to know that panic disorder is not a sign of weakness, and it does not mean something is ‚Äúbroken‚Äù in you. It is a learned pattern between your body and your mind‚Äîa system that has become oversensitive to normal sensations. And because it‚Äôs learned, it can also be unlearned. Therapy, gradual exposure, and calming techniques can retrain your brain to see these sensations for what they are: uncomfortable, but not dangerous.

findYourWayOut.title: Find your way out
findYourWayOut.subtitle: Explore and learn what you can do.
findYourWayOut.p1: The first step is understanding what panic really is. A panic attack is not a heart attack, not a sign you‚Äôre going crazy, and not something that will make you lose control forever. It is your body‚Äôs alarm system firing at the wrong time. Once you start to see the sensations‚Äîracing heart, tight chest, dizziness‚Äînot as danger but as your body‚Äôs survival response, they begin to lose some of their power.
findYourWayOut.p2: The next step is learning to stay with the discomfort instead of running from it. This may sound frightening at first, but it‚Äôs the key to breaking the cycle. Every time you avoid a place or situation, your brain learns, ‚ÄúYes, that was dangerous, and escaping saved me.‚Äù But every time you stay, even just for a little while, your brain learns, ‚ÄúThat wasn‚Äôt as dangerous as it felt. I can handle this.‚Äù Over time, this retrains your nervous system and reduces the frequency and intensity of attacks.
findYourWayOut.p3: The short version from modern CBT research and clinical guidelines is: the most effective way through a panic surge is to stop fighting it, stay where you are (if it‚Äôs safe), and let the sensations rise and fall while you do as little as possible to ‚Äúfix‚Äù them. This isn‚Äôt resignation; it‚Äôs exposure-with-acceptance, which teaches your brain there‚Äôs no danger here. Over repeated experiences, the fear-learning weakens and new ‚ÄúI‚Äôm safe‚Äù learning takes over. Leading guidelines for panic disorder place cognitive-behavioral therapy with exposure at the top for effectiveness, and newer ‚Äúinhibitory learning‚Äù models explain why allowing feelings (rather than escaping or calming them away) rewires fear more deeply.
findYourWayOut.p4: When a panic wave hits, think of it as your body‚Äôs alarm going off at the wrong time. If you can, pause where you are and notice the sensations with gentle curiosity: ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs the racing heart; here comes the heat in my face; my breath feels tight.‚Äù Don‚Äôt chase perfect breaths, don‚Äôt check your pulse, don‚Äôt scan for exits, and don‚Äôt open your phone to ‚Äúmake it stop.‚Äù These are safety behaviors, and although they bring short relief, they convince the brain the situation was dangerous and keep the cycle alive. Staying put and feeling the sensations (even if they spike) is the core of interoceptive exposure‚Äîthe deliberate practice of letting body feelings be there until your nervous system learns they‚Äôre uncomfortable, not catastrophic. Over time, this ‚Äúdo less, allow more‚Äù stance builds inhibitory learning: new, stronger memories that compete with the fear memory so the alarm quiets faster on its own.
findYourWayOut.p5: You don‚Äôt have to look calm or breathe ‚Äúperfectly‚Äù for this to work. In fact, exposure aims not for instant comfort but for new learning: ‚ÄúI can have dizziness and not faint; my heart can pound and I‚Äôm still safe; I can stay here until it passes.‚Äù Therapists often vary the context (different places, times, and body sensations) precisely to deepen this learning, because research shows that mixing it up prevents the brain from needing a special condition to feel safe. This is why many clinicians now coach patients to let anxiety rise, sometimes even provoking the sensations on purpose (spinning for dizziness, brisk stair climbs for heartbeat, holding the breath briefly for air hunger) and then doing nothing to neutralize them.

theCurveOfPanic.title: The Curve of Panic
theCurveOfPanic.subtitle: What maintains anxiety
theCurveOfPanic.p1: Think of panic like a wave. It rises, peaks, and then naturally falls.
theCurveOfPanic.p2: If you escape at the peak ‚Üí your brain never learns it would have fallen on its own.
theCurveOfPanic.p3: If you stay and do nothing ‚Üí you experience the full wave and prove to your brain: ‚Äúthe wave always passes.‚Äù
theCurveOfPanic.p4: The more waves you ride out, the less scary they become. This is how exposure therapy works‚Äîand it‚Äôs why most psychologists today agree that the best response is not to fight panic, but to let it happen.

rewireEffect.title: The Rewire Effect
rewireEffect.subtitle: How to rewire your brain
rewireEffect.p1: Every time you let panic come and go without interference:
rewireEffect.p2: Your amygdala learns that these sensations are not dangerous.
rewireEffect.p3: Your prefrontal cortex (the rational part of the brain) gets stronger at stepping in and saying, ‚ÄúThis is safe, I‚Äôve been here before.‚Äù
rewireEffect.p4: Your overall nervous system becomes less sensitive to small triggers.
rewireEffect.p5: This is why, with practice, panic disorder gets weaker. You‚Äôre literally retraining your brain‚Äôs alarm system to stay calm.
rewireEffect.p6: So the method isn‚Äôt about being passive or helpless‚Äîit‚Äôs active learning. By ‚Äúdoing nothing,‚Äù you‚Äôre actually doing the most powerful thing you can: teaching your brain that panic is safe to feel and doesn‚Äôt require rescue.

whyAllowingPanicHelps.title: Why Allowing Panic Works
whyAllowingPanicHelps.subtitle: (Brain-Level Explanation)
whyAllowingPanicHelps.p1: When you have a panic attack, your amygdala (the brain‚Äôs fear center) sounds the alarm. It releases adrenaline, speeds up your heart, and tightens your chest‚Äîall to prepare you to fight or run. The problem is: in panic disorder, this alarm goes off even though there‚Äôs no real danger.
whyAllowingPanicHelps.p2:
Now, here‚Äôs the key: every time you avoid or use safety behaviors (like leaving a situation, checking your pulse, or trying to calm yourself too hard), your brain learns:
üëâ ‚ÄúI survived because I escaped or because I controlled it.‚Äù
That reinforces the belief that panic is dangerous. The amygdala stays sensitive, and the cycle continues.
whyAllowingPanicHelps.p3:
But when you do nothing and simply feel the sensations, your brain gets a new lesson:
üëâ ‚ÄúI stayed. My heart raced, I felt dizzy, but nothing bad happened.‚Äù
This is called inhibitory learning. It doesn‚Äôt erase the old fear memory, but it builds a new, stronger memory on top of it: ‚Äúthese sensations are safe.‚Äù Over time, this new learning wins, and your alarm stops going off as often or as intensely.

whyThisFeelsHardAtFirst.title: Why This Feels Hard at First
whyThisFeelsHardAtFirst.p1: Doing nothing can feel like the opposite of what your body is screaming at you to do. That‚Äôs normal‚Äîyour alarm is convincing. But science shows that trying to calm down too much, controlling breathing, or escaping may actually slow recovery because it keeps the fear alive. Allowing discomfort teaches your brain faster that it‚Äôs not a threat.

exercisesInteroceptiveContent.title: Trigger Exercises
exercisesInteroceptiveContent.subtitle: Confront your triggers using interoceptive exposure exercises and become urself again
exercisesInteroceptiveContent.p1: Interoceptive exposure is a way to gently practice feeling the body sensations that usually scare you during a panic attack‚Äîlike a fast heartbeat, dizziness, or shortness of breath. Instead of avoiding them, you bring them on in a safe way and let yourself notice that nothing bad happens. The importance of this is that your brain starts to understand: ‚ÄúThese feelings are uncomfortable, but they are not dangerous.‚Äù Little by little, the fear loses its power, and panic attacks become less overwhelming. It‚Äôs like training your body and mind to stop seeing panic as a threat.

step1.title: Understand the Goal
step1.p1: You‚Äôre not trying to get rid of panic.
step1.p2: You‚Äôre training your brain to tolerate and accept the sensations without fear.
step1.p3: Think of it like going to the gym for your nervous system.

step2.title: Choose a Sensation to Practice
step2.description: Pick one body feeling that usually triggers panic:
step2.p1: Racing heart ‚Üí run in place for 60 seconds
step2.p2: Dizziness/lightheadedness ‚Üí spin in a chair for 30 seconds
step2.p3: Shortness of breath ‚Üí breathe quickly through a straw for 30 seconds
step2.p4: Chest tightness ‚Üí tense chest muscles and hold for 30 seconds
step2.p5: Warm flush ‚Üí wear a jacket indoors for a few minutes

step3.title: Set the Stage
step3.p1: Do this in a safe place where you won‚Äôt be interrupted.
step3.p2: Remind yourself: ‚ÄúThis is practice, not danger.‚Äù

step4.title: Induce the Sensation
step4.p1: Perform the exercise (e.g., spin, run, breathe fast).
step4.p2: Notice the body reaction coming up.

step5.title: Allow and Observe
step5.p1: Don‚Äôt fight it‚Äîjust watch the sensations rise.
step5.p2: Tell yourself: ‚ÄúThis is just adrenaline. I‚Äôm safe.‚Äù
step5.p3: Stay with it until the sensation peaks and naturally eases.

step6.title: Repeat Consistently
step6.p1: Do 1‚Äì2 exercises daily, a few minutes each.
step6.p2: Over time, your brain stops treating these sensations as threats.
step6.p3: You‚Äôll notice less fear, more control, and panic loses power.

step7.title: Gradual Progression
step7.p1: Start with the easiest sensations and work up to the hardest.
step7.p2: Eventually combine exposures with real-life (in vivo) exposures like standing in line, sitting in traffic, or staying in crowded places.

lightDizziness.title: Light Dizziness
lightDizziness.description: This is to make you feel a bit off balance while your brain catches up.
lightDizziness.content: Light dizziness is to make you feel a little wobbly, like your balance is off. You can trigger it by spinning gently in a chair or standing up quickly after sitting. This simulates the brief lightheadedness that can appear in a panic attack, reminding you it‚Äôs just your balance system adjusting. It usually fades within 5 to 30 seconds.

shortnessOfBreath.title: Shortness of Breath
shortnessOfBreath.description: This is to make you feel your chest tighten while your body reacts.
shortnessOfBreath.content: Shortness of breath is to make you feel like you can‚Äôt quite catch a full breath. You can trigger it by taking a few very fast, shallow breaths through your chest instead of your belly. This simulates the tight-chest breathing during panic, showing that even when it feels scary, you‚Äôre still getting enough oxygen. The sensation often lasts 30 to 90 seconds and eases as you slow your breathing.

racingHeart.title: Racing Heart
racingHeart.description: This is to make you feel your heart race as adrenaline kicks in.
racingHeart.content: A racing heart is to make you feel like it‚Äôs pounding out of your chest. You can trigger it by jogging in place, doing a set of jumping jacks, or running up stairs for 20‚Äì30 seconds. This simulates the adrenaline surge in a panic attack, showing that a fast heart is normal and safe when your body is activated. The pounding usually lasts 30 to 120 seconds before slowing.

heavyBreathing.title: Heavy Breathing
heavyBreathing.description: This is to make you feel tingly or lightheaded from fast breaths.
heavyBreathing.content: Heavy breathing is to make you feel breathless or tingly. You can trigger it by deliberately hyperventilating‚Äîbreathing quickly and shallowly for about 20 seconds. This simulates the breathlessness and tingling sensations during panic, teaching you that it‚Äôs caused by low CO‚ÇÇ and calms as soon as you breathe normally. It tends to last 20 to 60 seconds.

warmFlush.title: Warm Flush
warmFlush.description: This is to make you feel a quick warm flush as blood moves to your skin.
warmFlush.content: A warm flush is to make you feel suddenly hot or red in the face. You can trigger it by holding your breath for 10‚Äì15 seconds or sipping a hot drink. This simulates the rush of heat and redness during panic, reminding you it‚Äôs just blood moving toward your skin. It fades naturally in 30 to 60 seconds.

mooji.author: Mooji
mooji.text: Feelings are just visitors. Let them come and go.

buddhist.author: Inspired by Buddhist teaching
buddhist.text: Nothing in the mind is permanent, not even the storm of panic.

kabatZinn.author: Jon Kabat-Zinn
kabatZinn.text: You can‚Äôt stop the waves, but you can learn to surf.

angelou.author: Maya Angelou
angelou.text: This too shall pass. Every storm runs out of rain.

emerson.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
emerson.text: Feelings are just visitors. Let them come and go.

cbt.author: CBT principle
cbt.text: Your worst-case thoughts are not facts ‚Äî they are just thoughts.

unknown1.author: Unknown
unknown1.text: Breathe. You are stronger than you think, braver than you feel, and safer than you believe.

aliFear.author: Ali ibn Abi Taleb
aliFear.text: When you are afraid of something, throw yourself into it, for the intensity of the fear is greater than that of the thing itself.

exposure.author: Modern exposure therapy wisdom
exposure.text: Every time you let panic rise and fall, you are teaching your brain freedom.

aliRemedy.author: Ali ibn Abi Taleb
aliRemedy.text: Your remedy is within you, but you do not sense it. Your sickness is from you, but you do not perceive it.

9WaysToCalm.title: 9 Ways to Calm Yourself During a Panic Attack
9WaysToCalm.description: Each of these steps is small on its own, but together they retrain your brain‚Äôs alarm system. Over time, panic loses its grip, and you gain freedom.

remind.title: Remind yourself what it is
remind.text: When panic hits, the first instinct is often fear of the unknown‚Äî‚ÄúAm I dying? Is something wrong with me?‚Äù The most powerful step is to name it: ‚ÄúThis is a panic attack.‚Äù Reminding yourself that panic is your body‚Äôs alarm system misfiring‚Äînot a heart attack, not suffocation, not losing control‚Äîinstantly lowers the sense of mystery and danger. Naming it gives you a moment of perspective and tells your brain, ‚ÄúI know what this is, and I‚Äôve been here before.‚Äù

stay.title: Stay where you are
stay.text: Your brain wants you to run, escape, or grab safety. But escaping teaches the brain that the situation was indeed dangerous. If you can safely stay where you are‚Äîeven just for a minute longer‚Äîyou send the opposite message: ‚ÄúThis place is safe, even if my body feels scared.‚Äù Over time, choosing to stay helps retrain your brain so the next panic wave feels less threatening. The goal isn‚Äôt to trap yourself, but to gently practice presence until the fear curve eases.

allow.title: Let the sensations happen
allow.text: The more you fight panic sensations, the stronger they feel. Instead of resisting, let your body do what it does. Notice your heart racing, your breath tightening, or your hands trembling‚Äîthen say, ‚ÄúThis is just adrenaline. It‚Äôs not harmful.‚Äù By allowing the feelings to exist without rushing to stop them, your brain learns they are uncomfortable but not dangerous. This shift from fighting to allowing is the foundation of long-term recovery.

wave.title: Ride the wave
wave.text: Think of panic like an ocean wave: it rises, swells, and then always falls. If you surf it, you make it through; if you fight the wave, you struggle. Remind yourself, ‚ÄúThis panic will peak and pass.‚Äù Staying present through the curve teaches your nervous system that panic is temporary, not endless. You don‚Äôt need to force calm‚Äîyou just need to let the wave roll through and trust that your body knows how to settle itself.

breathing.title: Soften your breathing
breathing.text: During panic, many people breathe quickly and shallowly, which can worsen dizziness and chest tightness. Instead of forcing deep breaths, aim for soft, steady breathing: in through your nose, out through your mouth, slowly and gently. Think of sighing rather than controlling. Breathing this way signals your body‚Äôs calming system (the parasympathetic nervous system) and can take the edge off without turning into a ‚Äúrescue technique.‚Äù

ground.title: Ground yourself in the present
ground.text: Panic makes your attention spiral inward‚Äîinto your heartbeat, your lungs, your fears. To break this loop, gently shift your focus outward. Use grounding: notice 5 things you see, 4 things you feel, 3 things you hear. This isn‚Äôt about distracting yourself, but about reminding your brain: ‚ÄúThe world around me is steady and safe.‚Äù Grounding pulls you out of the storm in your body and anchors you back into the present moment.

dropSafety.title: Drop safety habits
dropSafety.text: It‚Äôs tempting to check your pulse, sip water, scroll your phone, or plan your exit whenever panic rises. While these feel helpful in the moment, they teach your brain that you need rescuing, which keeps panic alive. Dropping safety behaviors is hard, but each time you do, you prove to yourself that you can handle panic without crutches. This doesn‚Äôt mean stripping away all comfort at once, but gently practicing being with panic as it is‚Äîwithout reaching for rescue.

selfTalk.title: Use calming self-talk
selfTalk.text: Your inner voice can either fuel panic or soothe it. Instead of saying, ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt handle this‚Äù, try phrases like, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been through this before. My body knows how to calm down. Panic always passes.‚Äù Reassurance doesn‚Äôt make panic vanish instantly, but it shifts the tone inside your mind. Self-talk acts like a steadying hand on your shoulder‚Äîreminding you that you‚Äôre not in danger and that you have the strength to ride this wave.

wait.title: Wait for the curve
wait.text: Panic attacks are powerful but time-limited. Most peak within 5‚Äì10 minutes and then fade. The fear that it will ‚Äúnever stop‚Äù is part of the illusion. By waiting, without fighting, you prove to yourself that panic always ends. Think of it like a thunderstorm‚Äîit feels intense, but no storm lasts forever. Each time you let panic run its course, you build new evidence that the curve always comes down, and your brain gradually stops treating panic as a threat.

typesOfAnxiety.title: Understanding the Different Types of Anxiety
typesOfAnxiety.description: Anxiety disorders are among the most common mental health conditions. While occasional worry is normal, anxiety disorders cause intense, persistent fear or nervousness that interferes with daily life.

panicDisorder.title: Panic Disorder
panicDisorder.text: Panic disorder is marked by recurrent panic attacks‚Äîsudden waves of intense fear with strong body sensations like racing heart, shortness of breath, dizziness, or chest pain. People often fear losing control, fainting, or dying. Because attacks can feel unpredictable, many start to avoid certain places or activities, which can make the condition more limiting over time.

gad.title: Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD)
gad.text: GAD involves chronic, excessive worry about everyday things‚Äîwork, health, finances, relationships‚Äîoften even when there‚Äôs little reason for concern. People with GAD may feel restless, tense, tired, or struggle with concentration and sleep. Unlike panic disorder, GAD is more about constant background worry than sudden intense episodes.

socialAnxiety.title: Social Anxiety Disorder
socialAnxiety.text: Also called social phobia, this disorder is characterized by intense fear of being judged, embarrassed, or rejected in social situations. It goes beyond shyness‚Äîpeople may avoid parties, public speaking, or even everyday interactions like eating in front of others, which can strongly impact school, work, and relationships.

phobias.title: Specific Phobias
phobias.text: Phobias are intense, irrational fears of certain objects or situations‚Äîlike flying, heights, spiders, or blood. The fear is out of proportion to the actual danger, but the body reacts with strong anxiety or panic when faced with the phobic trigger. Many people go out of their way to avoid their feared object or situation.

agoraphobia.title: Agoraphobia
agoraphobia.text: Agoraphobia is the fear of being in places where escape might be difficult or help unavailable during a panic attack. Common fears include using public transport, being in open or crowded spaces, or leaving home alone. It often develops after repeated panic attacks and can sometimes keep people largely housebound.

separationAnxiety.title: Separation Anxiety Disorder
separationAnxiety.text: Most common in children, but it can also affect adults. It involves extreme distress when being apart from loved ones, often with worries that something bad will happen to them or to oneself. It goes beyond normal attachment and can interfere with daily functioning.

ptsd.title: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)
ptsd.text: Also distinct but related, PTSD involves anxiety symptoms after trauma, including flashbacks, avoidance, and hypervigilance.

ocd.title: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)
ocd.text: Once classified separately, OCD involves intrusive thoughts (obsessions) and repetitive behaviors (compulsions) to reduce anxiety.

commonSymptoms.title: Common Symptoms of Anxiety and Panic
commonSymptoms.description: Anxiety and panic affect both the mind and the body. While the intensity can differ from person to person, these are the most commonly experienced symptoms.

mental.title: Mental & Emotional Symptoms
mental.text: Excessive worry: Constant ‚Äúwhat if‚Äù thoughts about the future. Racing thoughts: Trouble slowing down your mind. Fear of losing control: Worry you might faint, ‚Äúgo crazy,‚Äù or embarrass yourself. Anticipatory anxiety: Fear of the next attack or stressful situation. Restlessness: Feeling on edge or unable to relax. Difficulty concentrating: Mind feels foggy or distracted. Irritability: Being more easily frustrated or tense.

physical.title: Physical Symptoms
physical.text: Racing heartbeat (palpitations): Feels like your heart is pounding or skipping beats. Shortness of breath: A tight chest, difficulty getting a deep breath. Chest pain or pressure: Often mistaken for a heart attack. Dizziness or lightheadedness: Feeling faint or unsteady. Sweating or chills: Sudden flushes of heat or cold. Shaking or trembling: Hands, legs, or full-body tremors. Muscle tension: Stiffness, especially in shoulders, jaw, or neck. Nausea or stomach upset: ‚ÄúButterflies,‚Äù cramps, or discomfort. Tingling or numbness: Often in hands, feet, or face. Difficulty sleeping: Trouble falling asleep or staying asleep due to worry.

panicSpecific.title: Symptoms Specific to Panic Attacks
panicSpecific.text: Panic attacks often bring sudden, intense versions of the symptoms above. They typically peak within 10 minutes and may include: Overwhelming sense of doom: Feeling like something terrible is happening. Fear of dying: Believing you‚Äôre having a heart attack or can‚Äôt breathe. Out-of-body feeling: Derealization (world feels unreal) or depersonalization (feeling disconnected from yourself).

important.title: Important to know:
important.text: These symptoms are real and can feel frightening, but they are the result of your body‚Äôs alarm system misfiring‚Äînot actual physical danger. Understanding them is the first step to breaking the fear cycle.

empty.title: No entries
empty.description: Journal analytics provide insights into your anxiety patterns over time. By logging entries, you can track symptoms, situations, and trends to better understand your mental health journey.

hero.title: Take your Life and Freedom back
hero.description: Each day is an opportunity to grow stronger against anxiety. Here you can set your personal daily challenge ‚Äî a step in exposure confrontation therapy. Choose a situation that triggers discomfort and commit to facing it today. You can start right away, or take the morning to prepare yourself and complete the challenge later in the day. What matters most is making the choice and giving yourself the chance to prove that you are safe, capable, and stronger than your fears.

alert.title: Why and for what is it good?
alert.description: Daily exposure challenges are a key part of confronting anxiety. By deliberately choosing a situation that triggers fear and committing to face it today, you teach your brain that these sensations and places are not dangerous. You may begin the challenge immediately or take time to prepare and carry it out later in the day. The important part is consistency: every exposure is a learning opportunity, and with each one, avoidance loses power and confidence grows.

typesOfBodySymptoms.title: Body sensations
typesOfBodySymptoms.subtitle: What did you feel in your body?

card.title: Box Breathing
card.subtitle: Regulate your breathing to calm your nervous system.

hints.inhale: Breathe in slowly through your nose.
hints.hold1: Gently hold. Stay soft in the shoulders.
hints.exhale: Breathe out slowly through your mouth.
hints.hold2: Hold. Notice the calm between breaths.

boxBreathing.completion: Nice work. Notice how your body feels now.

card.title: 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding
card.subtitle: Engage your senses to ground yourself in the present moment.

sheet.intro: Use your senses to return to the present.

see.title: 5 Things You Can See
see.subtitle: Look around and name five things.

taste.title: 1 Thing You Can Taste
taste.subtitle: Acknowledge one thing you can taste.

card.title: Physical Anchor
card.subtitle: Focus on a physical object to anchor yourself in reality.

meaning.title: What does it mean?
meaning.p1: A physical anchor is any tangible object you focus on with your senses to pull yourself back into the present moment. When anxiety or panic spirals, your mind can feel detached or overwhelmed. By concentrating on something real, solid, and right here, you remind your nervous system: I am safe, I am present.

steps.1: Pick an object near you (for example: a pen, a stone, your phone, keys, a cup, the edge of a chair).
steps.2: Look at it carefully. Notice its shape, size, colors, and tiny details.
steps.3: Touch it slowly. Feel the temperature, weight, texture, and edges. Run your fingers across it.
steps.4: Name what you notice out loud or in your mind. For example: ‚ÄúThis pen is smooth. It feels cool. It has black ink. It‚Äôs solid in my hand.‚Äù
steps.5: Stay with it for 30‚Äì60 seconds. Breathe slowly while keeping your attention on the object.

points.1: Interrupts spiraling thoughts by redirecting attention outward.
points.2: Reassures your body ‚Äî the solidity of an object contrasts the ‚Äúunreal‚Äù feeling of panic.
points.3: Engages multiple senses (sight, touch, sometimes even smell), which strengthens grounding.

card.title: Positive Reminders
card.subtitle: Reinforce positive beliefs to counteract negative thinking.

panicSupportPage.title: You're not alone
panicSupportPage.description: Remember, this feeling is temporary. You're strong, and you'll get through this. Focus on your breath and take it one step at a time.

4.label: 4 ‚Äì Noticeable
4.description: Clear anxiety, but can still function

8.label: 8 ‚Äì Intense
8.description: Difficult to stay present, fear is high

0.label: 0 - Very easy
0.description: Felt calm, no struggle at all

10.label: 10 - Overwhelming
10.description: Could not continue / had to stop

reassurances.panic_not_emergency: You are having a panic attack right now. I know it feels overwhelming, but this is not a medical emergency.
reassurances.body_is_safe: Your body is safe, even if the sensations feel scary. This is just your alarm system firing too strongly.
reassurances.panic_is_wave: Panic always comes in waves. It rises, it peaks, and it falls. All you need to do is ride the wave until it passes.
reassurances.no_need_to_escape: You don‚Äôt have to run away. You don‚Äôt have to escape. You can stay right here and be okay.
reassurances.just_adrenaline: What you are feeling right now is just adrenaline moving through your body. It is uncomfortable, but not dangerous.
reassurances.you_survived_before: You have been through this before, and every single time you made it through. This time is no different.
reassurances.body_knows_how: Even if your heart races or you feel dizzy, your body knows exactly how to calm itself down.
reassurances.no_fighting: You do not need to control or fight these sensations. Allow them to be here and let them fade naturally.
reassurances.others_cant_see: No one else can see what you are feeling inside. To the outside world, you look completely fine.
reassurances.teaching_your_brain: Right now, you are teaching your brain something powerful: these sensations are safe, and you do not need to fear them.
